topic.title: Perform cbq Access Tests
topic.shortdesc: By using cbq with appropriate username-password combinations, you can test Couchbase Role Based Access Control.

section.title: Access cbq
section.p: The cbq tool provides a command-line shell, whereby N1QL queries can be issued. See Browser and CLI Access for details on the tool's location. See Run Your First N1QL Query for an introduction to using Nq1QL.

section.title: Start and Manage a Reader-Session
section.p: RBAC requires that programs and applications authenticate with appropriate credentials, just like users. When you start a cbq session therefore, you must specify the username and password for the user who has been granted roles appropriate for tasks you wish to perform.
To start a cbq session for a reader of data, enter the following against the command-line prompt:
section.codeblock:
$ ./cbq -e http://localhost:8091 -u=composerReader -p=composerReader Connected to : http://localhost:8091/. Type Ctrl-D or \QUIT to exit.
Path to history file for the shell : /Users/tonyhillman/.cbq_history cbq>
section.p: The cbq prompt has now appeared, which means that you can enter N1QL queries for the user identified by the credential previously established for composerReader. Enter the follow N1QL query, to return all data from the composers bucket:
An error has been returned, indicating that no index yet exists on the composers bucket. To create an index, enter the following N1QL statement:
section.codeblock: cbq> CREATE PRIMARY INDEX composersIndex4 ON composers USING GSI;
section.p: The response to this index-creation directive is now as follows:

Another error has been returned, this time indicating that the current user does not belong to a specified role. This indicates that the role associated with the current user, that of read-access to data in the composers bucket, is insufficient to allow index-creation. Index-creation requires the Query Manage Index role, which you allocated to composerIndexMaker.

section.title: Start and Manage an Index-Writer Session
section.p: Exit the current cbq session by hiting Ctrl-D. Then, start a new session as follows:
section.codeblock:
$ ./cbq -e http://localhost:8091 -u=composersIndexMaker -p=composersIndexMaker Connected to : http://localhost:8091/. Type Ctrl-D or \QUIT to exit.
Path to history file for the shell : /Users/tonyhillman/.cbq_history cbq>
section.p: Note that the credentials with which you have started this new session are those of the user who was assigned the Query Manage Index role.
Re-attempt to create an index on the composers bucket, and observe the response.
The response contains a "status" value of "success". Therefore, queries can now be performed on bucket-data.

section.title: Re-start the Reader-Session
section.p: Again exit the current session by hitting Ctrl-D. Restart the session for the user composerReader, and again attempt to return all bucket-data:
This time, all data has been successfully returned. Continue by making a change to a data-element, and observing the response:

Again, an error is returned indicating that the user has the wrong role for the attempted operation. This is because the UPDATE operation requires read-write permission rather than read; and so must be performed by the previously defined composersReaderWriter user.
Again, exit the current cbq session by hitting Ctrl-D.

section.title: Start and Manage a Reader-Writer Session
section.p: Start a new cbq session, specifying the user with read-write permission on the bucket, perform the required UPDATE operation, and check the results by means of a subsequent query:
As the output confirms, the correct credentials for the write-operation were supplied, and the specified data-value was therefore successfully updated.
